quick_answer.what: Mayon is an active stratovolcano rising to 2,462 m (8,077 ft) above the Albay Gulf in the Bicol Region of southeastern Luzon, Philippines — widely considered the most perfectly shaped volcanic cone on Earth.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 2024. The most active volcano in the Philippines. Under continuous monitoring by PHIVOLCS.
quick_answer.famous_for: Its nearly perfect symmetrical cone, its devastating 1814 eruption that killed more than 1,200 people, and its frequent eruptions — 69 recorded since 470 CE.
quick_answer.danger_level: Very high — approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of the summit. Legazpi City (population ~210,000) lies just 13 km from the crater.

overview.content: Mayon Volcano (Filipino: Bulkang Mayon) is an active stratovolcano in the Philippines, rising to 2,462 m (8,077 ft) above the Albay Gulf on the southeastern coast of Luzon island. Renowned worldwide for its nearly perfect symmetrical cone — often described as the most beautifully shaped volcano on Earth — Mayon is also the most active volcano in the Philippines, with 69 recorded eruptions spanning more than 1,500 years. The volcano's eruptions range from gentle Strombolian lava fountaining to explosive Plinian events, with a cyclical pattern that typically begins with basaltic eruptions followed by longer periods of andesitic lava flows. Mayon sits within the Eastern Philippine Volcanic Arc, generated by the westward subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate. Its steep upper slopes funnel pyroclastic density currents and lahars down approximately 40 ravines radiating from the summit, repeatedly devastating the densely populated lowlands below. The volcano's deadliest eruption, in February 1814, killed more than 1,200 people and buried the town of Cagsawa — whose ruined church bell tower remains one of the Philippines' most iconic images. Despite the documented hazards, approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of Mayon's summit, and Legazpi City, the regional capital with a population of approximately 210,000, lies just 13 km from the crater. Mayon's combination of extraordinary beauty, extreme activity, and proximity to dense populations makes it one of the most active and most dangerous volcanoes in the Ring of Fire.

geology_and_formation.content: Mayon is a product of the Philippine subduction system, where the Philippine Sea Plate dives westward beneath the Eurasian Plate at a rate of approximately 60–80 mm per year along the Philippine Trench, located roughly 200 km to the east. The volcanic arc generated by this subduction process includes dozens of volcanoes stretching the length of the Philippine archipelago. Mayon's magma is predominantly andesitic to basaltic andesitic, typical of subduction zone volcanism where water-rich oceanic crust is dehydrated at depth, lowering the melting point of the overlying mantle wedge. The volcano has been built almost entirely during the Holocene, though its exact age is not precisely constrained. The remarkably symmetrical cone is a testament to the volcano's sustained central-vent eruption style: lava and tephra have been deposited evenly around the summit conduit, producing a textbook stratovolcano profile with slopes steepening from approximately 20° at the base to 35–40° near the summit. The small summit crater, approximately 200 m in diameter, is frequently modified by eruptions. Approximately 40 ravines (locally called 'barrancas') radiate from the summit like spokes of a wheel, carved by centuries of pyroclastic flows, lahars, and erosion. These channels serve as natural pathways for volcanic debris flows, directing hazardous material toward specific lowland communities. Mayon's geology records a pattern of cyclical activity: eruptions tend to begin with more mafic (basaltic) compositions and transition to more silicic (andesitic) compositions, reflecting progressive differentiation of magma batches in a shallow reservoir.

eruption_history_overview.content: Mayon's eruption record extends back to approximately 470 CE, with 69 eruptions documented through a combination of geological evidence, Spanish colonial records (from the 16th century onward), and modern monitoring. Of these 69 eruptions, 65 are classified as confirmed. The eruption frequency is remarkably high: since 1616 CE, when continuous historical records begin, Mayon has erupted at least 50 times, averaging approximately one eruption every 8 years. The volcano has produced two VEI 4 eruptions (1814 and 1897), fifteen VEI 3 events, and numerous smaller eruptions at VEI 0–2. The 19th century was particularly active, with more than 25 eruptions recorded between 1800 and 1900. In the 21st century, Mayon has continued its relentless activity with eruptions in 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2008, 2009–2010, 2013, 2014, 2018–2019, 2022, 2023–2024, 2024, and a possible event in 2025. This extraordinary eruption frequency makes Mayon one of the most active volcanoes in the world and the most active in the Philippines.

subsections.title: The 1814 Eruption — Mayon's Deadliest Event
subsections.content: The eruption of February 1, 1814, was the most devastating event in Mayon's recorded history and one of the deadliest volcanic eruptions in Philippine history. Rated VEI 4, the eruption produced massive pyroclastic flows and lahars that swept down the volcano's southwestern flanks, completely burying the town of Cagsawa and severely damaging Camalig, Budiao, and other settlements. More than 1,200 people were killed, with many deaths caused by pyroclastic density currents that overtook populated areas with little warning. The ruins of Cagsawa Church — only its bell tower remained visible above the volcanic deposits — became one of the Philippines' most recognized landmarks and a powerful symbol of volcanic hazard. The 1814 eruption ejected an estimated 50–60 million cubic meters of tephra and produced lahars that traveled more than 15 km from the summit, reshaping the landscape of the Albay lowlands.

subsections.title: The 1897 Eruption — A VEI 4 Event with Far-Reaching Lahars
subsections.content: Beginning on May 23, 1897, this VEI 4 eruption was the second-largest in Mayon's historical record. Powerful explosive activity generated a massive eruption column and pyroclastic density currents that devastated areas on the summit and south-southwest flanks. The eruption produced copious lahars (volcanic mudflows) that traveled far down multiple ravines, inundating low-lying agricultural areas. Though fewer fatalities were recorded than in 1814 — owing in part to prior evacuations — the eruption caused extensive destruction to infrastructure and farmland. The 1897 event demonstrated that Mayon remained capable of powerful explosive eruptions even in the modern era.

subsections.title: The 1984 Eruption — Modern Monitoring Saves Lives
subsections.content: The September 9, 1984, VEI 3 eruption was significant as one of the first Mayon eruptions to be monitored with modern seismic instrumentation. PHIVOLCS detected escalating seismicity and issued warnings that led to the evacuation of approximately 73,000 people from high-risk zones. The eruption produced pyroclastic flows that traveled up to 7 km from the summit, destroying several villages that had been evacuated. The successful prediction and evacuation response demonstrated the life-saving potential of volcanic monitoring and established a model for Philippine disaster preparedness that continues to guide responses today.

subsections.title: The 2018 Eruption — Spectacular Lava Fountains and Mass Evacuations
subsections.content: Beginning on January 13, 2018, Mayon entered a prolonged VEI 3 eruption that produced dramatic lava fountaining, pyroclastic flows, and thick ashfall across Albay Province. The eruption displaced more than 90,000 people, with communities within the 6 km permanent danger zone and the extended 8 km danger zone evacuated to temporary shelters. Spectacular lava fountains illuminated the night sky and were visible from Legazpi City. Pyroclastic density currents swept down the Miisi and Bonga ravines, reaching up to 5 km from the summit. Heavy rainfall during the eruption period generated lahars that damaged infrastructure and agricultural land. The eruption continued intermittently through 2019 and drew international media attention for the dramatic contrast between the glowing eruption and the volcano's elegant silhouette.

subsections.title: The 2023–2024 Eruption — Mayon's Ongoing Activity
subsections.content: Mayon entered an elevated period of unrest in mid-2023, with PHIVOLCS raising the alert level to Level 3 (increased tendency toward hazardous eruption) on June 8, 2023. The eruption produced lava flows that extended down the Miisi and Bonga channels, rockfall events visible from Legazpi City, and sulfur dioxide emissions exceeding 5,000 tonnes per day at peak activity. Approximately 87,000 people in communities within the extended danger zone were evacuated. The eruption continued intermittently into 2024, with PHIVOLCS maintaining close monitoring. This latest episode reinforced that Mayon remains one of the world's most persistently active volcanoes.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Mayon is monitored continuously by the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS), which operates the Mayon Volcano Observatory on Ligñon Hill, approximately 13 km from the summit. The monitoring network includes real-time seismic stations, electronic tilt and GPS instruments, visual and thermal cameras, sulfur dioxide flux measurements (using DOAS spectrometers), and acoustic sensors. PHIVOLCS uses a five-level alert system: Level 0 (no alert), Level 1 (abnormal, low-level unrest), Level 2 (moderate unrest), Level 3 (increased tendency toward hazardous eruption), Level 4 (hazardous eruption imminent), and Level 5 (hazardous eruption in progress). As of late 2024, Mayon returned to a lower alert level following the 2023–2024 activity, though continued seismic events, elevated sulfur dioxide flux, and ground deformation indicate the volcano remains in a state of unrest. A permanent 6 km radius danger zone around the summit is enforced at all times, with extensions up to 8–9 km during periods of elevated activity. The frequency of Mayon's eruptions — averaging roughly once every 8 years over the past four centuries — means that the next eruption is a matter of when, not if.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Mayon poses multiple severe volcanic hazards to a densely populated region. Pyroclastic density currents (high-speed avalanches of hot gas and rock) are the deadliest threat, capable of traveling up to 10 km from the summit at speeds exceeding 100 km/h and temperatures above 300°C. The ~40 ravines radiating from the summit channel these flows directly toward populated areas. Lahars — volcanic mudflows triggered by rainfall on loose volcanic deposits — are a persistent secondary hazard that continues long after eruptions end, traveling down the ravines to inundate low-lying communities, farms, and infrastructure. During the rainy season, lahar-generating events can occur years after the eruption that produced the source deposits. Lava flows from Mayon typically extend 3–7 km down the steep upper slopes but rarely reach populated areas directly. Tephra fall (volcanic ash and rock fragments) can blanket areas up to 30+ km downwind, collapsing roofs, contaminating water supplies, and damaging crops. Volcanic gases, particularly sulfur dioxide, pose health hazards to downwind communities. The population exposure is extreme: approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of the summit, and Legazpi City (population ~210,000) lies within 13 km. The 6 km permanent danger zone was established to provide a safety buffer, but informal settlements and agricultural activities frequently encroach on restricted areas. Mayon's hazard profile is comparable to Merapi in Indonesia and Fuego in Guatemala — densely populated stratovolcanoes in the Ring of Fire with frequent explosive eruptions.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Mayon rises from near sea level to 2,462 m (8,077 ft) in a nearly unbroken conical profile, producing one of the most geometrically perfect volcanic cones on Earth. The base diameter is approximately 130 km in circumference, and the slopes increase from approximately 20° at lower elevations to 35–40° near the summit. The small summit crater, roughly 200 m in diameter, is frequently reconfigured by eruptions and may be open or plugged at any given time. Approximately 40 deeply incised ravines (locally called 'barrancas' or 'gullies') radiate from the summit, carved by centuries of pyroclastic flows, lahars, and erosion. These channels play a critical role in directing volcanic hazards: during eruptions, they concentrate pyroclastic flows and lahars into specific downslope paths, creating alternating zones of high and lower risk between the ravines. The Mayon Volcano Natural Park, established in 2000, encompasses 5,775 hectares of the upper slopes, protecting remnant tropical forests on the lower flanks while accommodating the permanent danger zone. The lower slopes transition from barren lava fields and lahar deposits through scrubland to lush tropical vegetation, including coconut and abaca (Manila hemp) plantations that sustain the regional economy. The Albay Gulf to the southeast provides a dramatic coastal backdrop, and on clear days Mayon is visible from Legazpi City's waterfront — one of the world's most striking volcano-city vistas.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Mayon's eruptions have been primarily regional in their climatic impact. None of its historically recorded eruptions have been large enough to inject significant volumes of sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere at levels that would produce measurable global cooling. The 1814 VEI 4 eruption, while devastating locally, released far less material than globally significant eruptions like Pinatubo's 1991 VEI 6 event, which occurred just 350 km to the northwest and produced approximately 0.5°C of global cooling. Mayon's more typical VEI 2–3 eruptions inject ash and gases into the troposphere, affecting regional air quality, agriculture, and aviation. Sulfur dioxide emissions from Mayon during active phases regularly exceed 5,000 tonnes per day, contributing to volcanic smog ('vog') that affects air quality in Albay Province and beyond. The persistent lahar hazard following eruptions has long-term effects on local rivers, agriculture, and sediment transport into the Albay Gulf, impacting coastal ecosystems and fisheries.

cultural_significance.content: Mayon holds a central place in Filipino culture, regional identity, and the heritage of the Bicol Region. The volcano's name derives from the Bicolano word 'magayon,' meaning 'beautiful' — a name memorialized in the Bicolano legend of Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), a tragic love story in which the heroine is killed and her burial mound becomes the volcano. This legend remains a vital element of Bicolano cultural identity and has inspired countless artistic works, festivals, and literary pieces. The Cagsawa Ruins — the partially buried bell tower of the church destroyed in the 1814 eruption — are one of the Philippines' most photographed and visited heritage sites, drawing hundreds of thousands of visitors annually and serving as a sobering reminder of volcanic hazard. Mayon features prominently in Filipino visual art, photography, and tourism branding, and its perfect cone is used as a symbol of Albay Province and the Bicol Region. The annual Ibalong Festival in Legazpi City celebrates Bicolano mythology and history, with Mayon as a central motif. The volcano also plays an important role in agricultural culture: the fertile volcanic soils on Mayon's lower slopes support productive coconut, abaca, and rice cultivation that forms the backbone of the regional economy.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Mayon Volcano Natural Park and the surrounding area offer numerous tourism opportunities, though access to the volcano itself is restricted by the 6 km permanent danger zone. The most popular viewing point is at the Cagsawa Ruins, where the partially buried church bell tower provides an iconic foreground for photographs of the perfect cone. Ligñon Hill Nature Park in Legazpi City offers panoramic views from a vantage point approximately 13 km from the summit, with walkways, a viewing deck, and a zipline. The Mayon Skyline viewpoint, accessible by vehicle on the upper slopes (within security limits), provides closer views. ATV (all-terrain vehicle) tours operate on Mayon's lower slopes, riding over lahar deposits and lava fields. When alert levels permit, guided trekking to the designated safe boundaries is available. Full summit climbs were historically possible but are rarely permitted due to the persistent volcanic hazard. Visitors should always check the current PHIVOLCS alert level before planning activities near Mayon. Legazpi City serves as the tourism base, with hotels, restaurants, and the Albay Park and Wildlife center. The wider Bicol Region offers additional attractions including Donsol whale shark watching, Caramoan Islands, and CamSur Watersports Complex.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Mayon is part of the Eastern Philippine Volcanic Arc, a chain of volcanoes generated by the subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate. The nearest significant volcano is Bulusan (1,565 m), approximately 75 km to the southeast in Sorsogon Province, which has erupted 17 times since 1852 and most recently in 2022. Further north on Luzon, Pinatubo (1,486 m) — site of the massive VEI 6 eruption in 1991 — lies approximately 350 km to the northwest. Taal (311 m), one of the world's smallest active volcanoes with its caldera-within-a-caldera, is approximately 380 km northwest near Manila. The Philippines hosts 23 Holocene volcanoes in the Smithsonian database, making it one of the most volcanically active countries in the Ring of Fire. Together, these volcanoes pose ongoing hazards to the country's population of over 110 million.

etymology.content: The name Mayon derives from the Bicolano word 'magayon,' meaning 'beautiful' — a testament to the volcano's extraordinary visual symmetry. The name is rooted in the legend of Daragang Magayon ('Beautiful Maiden'), a Bicolano origin myth in which a young woman's grave becomes the volcano. In Filipino usage, the full name 'Bulkang Mayon' (Mayon Volcano) is common. Early Spanish colonial records refer to the volcano as 'Volcán de Albay,' after the surrounding province.

faqs.question: Is Mayon Volcano active?
faqs.answer: Mayon is not just active — it is the most active volcano in the Philippines and one of the most frequently erupting volcanoes in the world. With 69 recorded eruptions since 470 CE, Mayon has averaged approximately one eruption every 8 years over the historical period. The volcano has erupted 20 times in the 21st century alone (2001–2025), including significant events in 2018 and 2023–2024. PHIVOLCS monitors Mayon continuously using seismometers, GPS, gas sensors, and visual cameras. The volcano is classified as active with a permanent 6 km danger zone around the summit.

faqs.question: When did Mayon last erupt?
faqs.answer: Mayon's most recent confirmed eruption began in May 2024, following a period of elevated activity that started in mid-2023. The 2023–2024 episode produced lava flows that advanced down the Miisi and Bonga ravines, rockfall events, and elevated sulfur dioxide emissions. PHIVOLCS raised alert levels and evacuated tens of thousands of residents from communities within the expanded danger zone. Prior to this, a significant VEI 3 eruption in January 2018 produced spectacular lava fountains and displaced over 90,000 people.

faqs.question: How tall is Mayon Volcano?
faqs.answer: Mayon rises to 2,462 m (8,077 ft) above sea level, making it the highest point in the Bicol Region of southeastern Luzon, Philippines. Because the volcano rises from near sea level at the Albay Gulf coast, its full height of nearly 2,500 m is visible in profile — contributing to its dramatic visual impact. Mayon's summit elevation is comparable to other major Philippine volcanoes: Apo (2,954 m, Mindanao) is taller, while Pinatubo (1,486 m, Luzon) and Taal (311 m, Luzon) are shorter.

faqs.question: Why is Mayon's cone so perfect?
faqs.answer: Mayon's nearly perfect symmetrical cone results from its sustained central-vent eruption style. Unlike volcanoes that erupt from multiple flank vents or fissures — which creates irregular shapes — Mayon's eruptions consistently originate from the central summit conduit. Lava, tephra, and pyroclastic material are deposited relatively evenly around the vent, building a symmetrical cone over centuries. The approximately 40 evenly spaced ravines that radiate from the summit also contribute by distributing erosional processes uniformly around the cone. The frequent eruption rate helps maintain the shape by constantly adding fresh material before erosion can create significant asymmetry.

faqs.question: How many people live near Mayon?
faqs.answer: Approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of Mayon's summit, making it one of the most densely populated volcanic hazard zones on Earth. Legazpi City, the capital of Albay Province with a population of approximately 210,000, lies just 13 km from the crater. Other municipalities within the hazard zone include Camalig, Guinobatan, Daraga, and Santo Domingo. A permanent 6 km radius danger zone around the summit is enforced, but informal settlements and agricultural activities frequently encroach on restricted areas. PHIVOLCS maintains evacuation plans for communities in the extended danger zones.

faqs.question: What happened in the 1814 eruption?
faqs.answer: The eruption of February 1, 1814, was Mayon's deadliest event, killing more than 1,200 people. Rated VEI 4, the eruption produced massive pyroclastic flows and lahars that swept down the southwestern flanks. The town of Cagsawa was completely buried, with only the church bell tower remaining visible above the volcanic deposits — ruins that are now one of the Philippines' most iconic heritage sites. The nearby towns of Camalig and Budiao were also severely damaged. The eruption ejected an estimated 50–60 million cubic meters of tephra and produced lahars that traveled more than 15 km from the summit.

faqs.question: Can you visit Mayon Volcano?
faqs.answer: Mayon and its surrounding area offer numerous tourism experiences, though access is restricted by the permanent 6 km danger zone. The most popular viewing point is the Cagsawa Ruins, where the iconic buried church bell tower provides a dramatic foreground for photographs. Ligñon Hill Nature Park in Legazpi City offers panoramic views from approximately 13 km away. ATV tours operate on the lower slopes over lahar deposits. When alert levels permit, guided treks approach the designated safety boundary. Full summit climbs are rarely permitted due to persistent volcanic hazard. Visitors should always check the current PHIVOLCS alert level before planning activities near the volcano.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Mayon?
faqs.answer: Mayon is classified as a stratovolcano (also called a composite volcano), the same type as Fuji, Vesuvius, and Pinatubo. Stratovolcanoes are built from alternating layers of lava flows, tephra, and pyroclastic material, producing the classic steep-sided conical shape. Mayon's eruptions range from gentle Strombolian lava fountaining (small explosions projecting incandescent lava fragments) to explosive sub-Plinian and Plinian events producing eruption columns reaching 15+ km altitude. The volcano's magma is predominantly andesitic to basaltic andesitic, typical of subduction zone volcanism in the Philippine Sea Plate system.
